subject: Re: [junit] a test pattern ?
msgSnippet: ... Google on data-driven junit test suite, or see JUnit Recipes. James
messageBody:
On 4/23/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Chris Downey wrote:
>
> > This was great... until I realized that I need at least 5-10
> > variations on the values in order to test what happens if a zero or a
> > null is included in the ProjectCostCalculator parms. Any ideas on the
> > best way to approach test design when you need to run it multiple
> > times with different data configurations?
> >
>
> Don't use fixtures. Just set up each such test as a separate test method
> using local variables. I've never been all that fond of fixtures myself,
> and IMHO a bit too much emphasis is put on them in the JUnit docs and
> tutorials. They're occasionally useful, but more often they're more
> trouble than they're worth.
>
> --
> Elliotte Rusty Harold elharo@...
> XML in a Nutshell 3rd Edition Just Published!
> http://www.cafeconleche.org/books/xian3/
> http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN=0596007647/cafeaulaitA/ref=nosim
>

Google on data-driven junit test suite, or see JUnit Recipes.

James
